The Chinese steel PMI data implies another strong month ahead for the miners with our Restocking Indicator delivering a reading of 1.26, comfortably above the 1.1 Buy threshold. All key components continue to point to bullish industrial commodity prices for the month ahead - new orders were up at 66, finished steel inventories are expected to de-stock with a reading of 43 and iron ore will restock with a reading of 53.

BE11:15am

Corporate activity. While we do not base
our analysis on potential takeover valuations,
we do think that M&A activity in the space
would be a key upward risk to our intu
valuation, and therefore our intu price target.
Westfield's statement from 23 February 2017
that it has taken a small stake in intu is
drawing increasing attention to this debate.

undefined
11:19 am
PM11:19am

See this AZ stuff from Japan?

BE11:20am

About not buying thingmybob? Yep.

PM11:20am

Stale, but interesting i thought

11:20 am
PM11:20am

Britain’s AstraZeneca PLC offered to buy peer Daiichi Sankyo Co Ltd last year, a business magazine reported on Thursday, sending the Japanese drugmaker’s share price soaring as much as 13 percent and triggering a trade suspension.

BE11:20am

It is. What's most interesting is that AZ thinks it can buy things.

PM11:20am

Exactly

11:20 am
PM11:21am

And this was a putative $16bn deal

PM11:21am

So AZ thinks it can buy big, expensive things

BE11:21am

(@Kate Allen: thanks. Remember the reports. But he's not above the disclosure limit, which for him would mean a sub 3% stake, right?)

11:21 am
BE11:22am

Even though it needs to keep selling its pipeline to pay its dividend.

PM11:22am

Here's Reuters on the matter https://www.reuter...neca-idUSKCN1BB0FQ

BE11:23am

So, let me get an explainer on Daiichi Sankyo.

11:23 am
BE11:24am

Here's UBS.

BE11:24am

We were surprised by the news. A 20% premium on undisturbed Daiichi Sankyo shares would require a bid of c.$20bn for full ownership. On 2016 numbers, AstraZeneca had net debt / EBITDA of 1.46x and "core" EBITDA of ~$7.3bn. However, this was, and remains, boosted substantially by externalisation revenues and product disposals ($3.4bn in 2016). This makes the gearing required for a full acquisition look challenging in our view. Perhaps some other structure would have been more affordable (e.g., along the lines of Roche and Chugai)? Also, it seems strange to us for a company like Astra, which is taking exceptional measures to fund its own R&D (e.g., externalisation revenues), to pay a premium for someone else's R&D.

BE11:24am

(@Kate: I stand corrected, thanks.)

11:25 am
BE11:25am

On the other hand, we can see several reasons why a deal might have made sense. AstraZeneca and Daiichi Sankyo have several partnerships already: Daiichi distributes Nexium in Japan and co-commercialises Movantik in the US. There may be some common interests in cardio-renal drugs. Daiichi Sankyo has a partnership with Vifor to copromote iron products Venofer and Ferinject. AZN has a HIF inhibitor in late-stage development (roxadustat), as well as the potassium binder, ZS-9. Daiichi has its own Factor Xa edoxaban, an oral anti-coagulant. AstraZeneca has Brillinta, an anti-platelet agent. There is also possible complementarity in antibody-drug conjugates (ADCs), where Daiichi has DS-8201, an HER2-targeting ADC (a "next generation" Kadcyla) in late stage trials (however, this is now partnered with Bristol-Myers Squibb for combination with Opdivo in HER-2 expressing breast and bladder tumours). Astra have four ADC clinical programmes including moxetumomab in PIII.

BE11:26am

I think they mean Brilinta rather than Brillinta, by the way.

PM11:26am

ok

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Though saying ticagrelor would be better. Because one's a compound and the other's a brand.

PM11:27am

I'll let UBS know

BE11:27am

Note also it's ESMO this week.

11:27 am
PM11:27am

Course it is

BE11:27am

The industry's big cancer conference.

BE11:27am

Madrid. Actually, not this week at all now I check. 8-12 September

11:28 am
BE11:28am

But the big data drop was last night. 1.5k abstracts.

BE11:29am

Most are fairly dull. The exciting stuff gets held back for on-the-day release.

BE11:30am

Which will include PACIFIC /FLAURA for AstraZeneca.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

Want something deeply native from Barclays?

PM11:30am

Er, sure

BE11:30am

From AZN we look for strong results in PACIFIC (e.g. HR less than 0.7 with clean risk-benefit) and FLAURA (e.g. PFS pushing the 19-20month mark) to validate our positive stance on both datasets. As regards the ESMO abstracts released last night we note that the P2 single arm HAWK data for Imfinzi in HSNCC shows a 13.5% ORR which looks unimpressive vs the high-teens ORRs seen elsewhere (e.g. 18% for Keytruda in KN012/055) whilst the P1b/2 SCORES study of Imfinzi in combination with STAT3 inhibitor AZD9150 or CXCR2 inhibitor AZD5069, in patients with HNSCC looks encouraging but very early. Whilst an initial broader review of the ESMO abstracts released last night suggests little of immediate high impact (e.g. an incremental update of Incyte’s epacadostat+pembro data in melanoma), we expect the late-breaking data released during the conference to be of relevance. In particular we will be looking at: From BMY (Geoff Meacham, EW) PD1+CTLA4 1L renal data (CM214) and PD1 monotherapy data in TNBRC, along with LAG3+PD1 combination data in melanoma. From LLY (Geoff Meacham, OW) the P3 abemaciclib MONARCH-3 data will likely confirm its position as a competitive 3rd entrant in the CDK4/6 space with a particular focus on the risk-benefit profile vs PFE’s Ibrance and NOVN’s Kisqali, whilst from MRK (Geoff Meacham, OW) we will see updated KN021G data for PD1+chemo in 1L NSCLC along with other important data such as the KN040 failure in HNSCC

11:30 am
BE11:31am

I hope all AZN investors are fully across all that, otherwise they're not making an informed decision.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Nortek margins are improving steadily as management do the Spanish archer thing.

BE11:37am

That offsets Brush trading getting worse.

BE11:38am

Numbers are either ahead or behind depending on which broker you read, but the focus has now moved on to the next deal anyway.

11:38 am
PM11:38am

Apparently they are busy looking

BE11:38am

Have JP Morgan Caz.

BE11:38am

A combination of some analyst expectations running ahead of management’s commentary and the increased FX headwind may see top-of-the-range estimates come down slightly but we see underlying trading very much inline at the group level. Bigger picture, we do not see small changes in earnings as important with the key for the stock being the next deal where management confirms they have explored potential opportunities recently and remain confident in finding the right acquisition target. We remain Overweight.

11:39 am
BE11:39am

And Stifel.

BE11:40am

Melrose published its interim results this morning, and while they are ahead of consensus on revenue, and beat our margin assumptions in Nortek, the overall results are somewhat light at the earnings level at 4.9p vs. consensus at 5.0p, and our expectations of 5.3p. This appears to have been driven by an unexpectedly weak performance in Ergonomics, and the Brush businesses getting even worse - we had hoped to see stabilization in the latter. The update on acquisitions is understandably quite brief and non-specific; stating simply that management have been busy exploring opportunities and remain confident in their ability to find the right deal. Unpicking this slightly disappointing statement does however reveal a few more positive highlights, Air Management and Security and Smart Technology are performing very strongly, and the business has made significant investment (over £47m) in production efficiencies and new sales channels, which we think will pay dividends in forthcoming periods. Furthermore, we continue to believe that an announcement on the next deal, although impossible to predict in terms of timing, will drive an immediate uplift.

BE11:41am

I think the management presentation is ongoing, by the way, and would be cautious about taking a directional opinion before that finishes.

11:42 am
PM11:42am

fair enough

BE11:42am

22x 2017 already prices in management's delivery record, so Melrose remains a punt on history repeating as much as anything.

undefined
11:43 am
BE11:43am

What else? There's Restaurant Group getting some attention on the right.

PM11:43am

Few other results related moves...

Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 347.96, up 29.86 (+9.39%), High: 362.80, Low: 328.20, Volume: 2.35m
11:43 am
PM11:43am

Scorchedfingers for the shorts there

PM11:43am

ScorchedfingersScorchedfingers

PM11:43am

https://www.invest...1708310700033591P/

11:43 am
BE11:44am

Yep, it's an exciting rally back to where it was four days ago.

BE11:44am

PM11:44am

Frankie & Benny's said to be on the mend

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Yeah, well .................

PM11:44am

You don't like this business!

PM11:44am

Or don't like it's offering

11:44 am
BE11:44am

It's not that at all. I think it's more that the market was sufficiently primed for LFL to be terrible.

BE11:45am

Which it is, so the price has swung on "green shoots" guidance.

BE11:45am

(It would be cheap to note that "green shoots" are something rarely seen on Frankie & Benny's menus.)

11:46 am
BE11:46am

..... as in, initial footfall at retail locations and stuff.

BE11:47am

Plus, we've said a lot about the restaurant market being tough right now -- which it isn't. Consumer spending's still amazingly resilient and services are still growing as a slice of the wallet.

BE11:48am

The fact that the industry ate itself with too much cheap capital going into nonsense rollouts doesn't make for a tough backdrop. Anyway, back to subject.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Here's Barclays.

BE11:48am

H1 17 PBT was £25.5m vs £36.6m in H1 16, and adjusted EPS was 10p vs 14.3p in the prior year (H1 16 was a 27 week period vs 26 weeks in H1 17). The dividend was held at 6.8p, and Net Debt fell to £19.3m vs £35.8m in FY16, both of which are encouraging part way through the turnaround. FCF was £35.1m, down only slightly year on year from £35.8m driven by a significant reduction in cash tax to £1.7m from £9m (we assume this is not sustainable in the long term) and a reduction in maintenance capex to £8.7m vs £15.7m in H1 16. Maintenance capex looks likely to pick up in H2, with FY17 guidance of c£20m.

BE11:49am

There are some other clear positives in this statement.

· The company is reporting early signs of “improved volume momentum in our Leisure business”. This follows significant discounting throughout the year, combined with menu price cuts at Frankie & Benny’s, with entry prices reported as being reduced in today’s statement by 22% with LFL dishes 7% cheaper. Ultimately, we agree that pursuit of volume gains is the key to the investment case from here so these early improvements are encouraging.

· Cost savings have come through faster than expected, with £10m of cost savings expected in FY17 vs FY16, whereas the company has previously reported that it could achieve this sort of saving in the medium term. The company comments that this is supporting their “reinvestment in price, product and marketing”.

11:49 am
BE11:49am

However, we would flag some negative points:

· It is clear that slower LFLs and discounting are having a material impact on margins, with EBIT margins down to 7.9%, a 260 bps fall vs H1 16.

· LFL sales growth has slowed to -2.2% in H1 17 (26 weeks) vs -1.8% LFLs stated at the AGM (20 weeks). After 34 weeks, LFLs have moved down again to -2.5%. This is to be expected vs the AGM statement given the slower cinema attendance figures in May and June, and material price cuts, but illustrates the challenge of the task in hand. In addition, menu changes at other brands such as Coast to Coast and Chiquito’s are still to come which may also lower overall prices.

· Finally, there are more exceptional items of £22.7m, comprising £4.4m of property provisions after the successful exit of 12 sites, but after a review of the remaining disposal sites and a further estate review. There is also a rise in the onerous lease provision of £9.8m due to “a change in the discount rate applied to the onerous lease”, another impairment charge of £4.3m made against the carrying value of some restaurant assets, and £4.2m relating to restructuring projects. Although many of these items are non-cash, how all these factors impact the P&L in FY17 and future years is unclear.

BE11:49am

Overall, our view is little changed by these results. Restaurant Group management appears to be taking many sensible steps to turnaround performance for the long term. This is creating significant P&L headwinds in the short term to create a more sustainable volume led recovery. The FY17E FCF yield of c10% is certainly attractive, but investors in the pubs and restaurant sector have significant choice at similar valuations without the execution risk of a turnaround. Although the pub stocks have significant balance sheet Debt, they have freehold assets (much lower at Restaurant Group) that in some cases that could act as more of a valuation cushion in the event of a greater downturn in trading.

BE11:50am

Peel Hunt, who remain cautious on unchanged forecasts.

11:50 am
BE11:50am

We are holding our forecasts, although with further price cutting, the risk to 2018E forecasts is on the downside.

BE11:51am

For the full year, we forecast LFL sales to fall by 2.7%, which reflects the increased impact food price reductions (with Chiquito and Coast to Coast/Firejacks also cutting prices from September), and a slightly less helpful cinema/airport volume backdrop.

BE11:51am

In 2018E, there should be similar cost pressures, against which there should be less incremental costs savings (as they were fast-tracked into 2017E) and less incremental closure savings. Thus, we expect the company to require 1.5-2.0% LFL sales to hold profits flat. Due to the short-term impact of the price reductions, the company should be better placed to achieve a LFL sales recovery in H2 2018 than in H1, in our view.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Although LFL trading weakened in Q2, management has stated that new menus are gaining positive feedback and traction. Another positive is that the dividend has been held for these results, but with price cuts weighted to Q2 and Q3 2017, we expect 2018E to also be a transitional year. If profits fall again in 2018E, the dividend will be at risk, in our view.

BE11:53am

All of which seems reasonable, right? You're paying 14 times for a business where LFL must've been down 3.5% in the most recent quarter, whose margins went down 330 bips, and which is frontloading cost savings.

BE11:53am

I mean, good luck.

11:53 am
PM11:53am

hehe

11:54 am

PM11:55am

PM11:56am

11:56 am
PM11:56am

After warning on... US textbook sales

PM11:56am

Here's a snap from LIberum

PM11:57am

Barnes & Noble Education (N/R), one of the largest college bookstore operators in North America reported Q1’18 results yesterday and the shares were down c.17% after numbers came in below consensus estimates. The read across to Pearson is from BNED’s comparable store textbook sales which declined 8.5%. This is a further acceleration from the 6.8% decline in Q1’17. Pearson’s North American Higher Education business remains our key concern and accounted for an estimated 34% of FY’16 operating profit and these results point to a potential acceleration of the decline in textbook sales seen in 2016 which would further negatively impact this business.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

The decline of US textbook sales is one of those oddities. It looked like an unsustainable system that exploited the consumer. A lot of people said this. The textbook publishers continued regardless. The system gradually fell apart and sales collapsed.

BE11:59am

It's like a slow-motion version of how investing's supposed to go.

BE11:59am

Next to fall, of course, is the journal system.

11:59 am
BE11:59am

http://www.science...oomed-data-analyst

BE12:00pm

Then after that, newspapers.

undefined
12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Alfa requested. We can do that, even though it's midday.

BE12:01pm

Maiden results, FTSE 250 inclusion, big squeeze.

BE12:02pm

Let me get Barclays to summarise.

12:02 pm
BE12:03pm

Alfa had a solid set of maiden results with 1H revenues +57% YoY (+29% const. FX, adj.) and adj. EBIT up 36% (+20% const. FX), resulting in revenues that were 3% ahead of our estimate with profit in line. It reiterated its FY guidance of “highteens” revenue growth and a flat margin. We increase our estimates marginally to stay within guidance, although we believe upside is building, particularly to revenues. As highlighted in our initiation, we see Alfa as a premium asset that will disproportionately benefit from the upgrade cycle in the asset finance industry, driven by the need to reduce costs and digitalise business processes. However, we believe this is currently in the valuation and we reiterate our Equal Weight. Our 440p price target is based on 35x FY18E PE, which drops to 29x in our “blue sky” scenario.

BE12:04pm

Oh! Numis covers as well.

BE12:04pm

Alfa's maiden interims show revenue £45.1m +29% ccy vs NSe £41.5m, and adjusted EBIT £21.4m vs NSe £19.5m, +20% ccy, although the H1 figures do benefit from £2m of revenue and EBIT falling earlier in the year than was originally expected. Given contract progress, Alfa's strong market position, and the H1 performance, we move our FY and outer year forecasts up 3-4%. We think the current year is well-underpinned by existing business, with a strong pipeline potentially supporting good upside to FY18 forecasts. We retain our 522p valuation, and following recent share price weakness with the shares now on under 30x CY19 EV:NOPAT we upgrade to Buy.

12:05 pm
undefined
PM12:05pm

Thanks for all that Bryce

PM12:05pm

And cheers for joining us over on the right

12:05 pm
PM12:05pm

Back tomorrow at 11am sharp

PM12:05pm

Bye

BE12:06pm

(@DJ: $5m, 36 days volume.)
